medical_history.chief_complaint: Tardive dyskinesia secondary to long-term neuroleptic therapy.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Mr. A, a 19-year-old man, has a 6-year history of undifferentiated schizophrenia and displayed symptoms of tardive dyskinesia after a history of antipsychotic medication, particularly worsened post-reserpine discontinuation. His tardive dyskinesia symptoms, including buccal-facial-mandibular movements and neck hyperextension, progressed over time, especially after stopping reserpine treatment.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Long-term neuroleptic therapy, including previous medications like trifluoperazine, thioridazine, chlorpromazine, and others, which led to the development of tardive dyskinesia.
medical_history.family_history: Father has a chronic benign facial tic, a probable predisposing factor for Mr. A's tardive dyskinesia. Maternal grandmother treated with ECT at age 65 and paternal great-uncle with multiple psychiatric hospitalizations.
medical_history.social_history: Mr. A lived at home with family, was able to take care of personal hygiene, prepare food, and engage in sports activities. Notable for being unable to work or finish high school.
